title: The best worst case scenario in MasterMind
body: In the game of MasterMind , you are trying to guess a sequence of colours.  After each guess, your guess is graded: you find out how many are exactly right, and how many others are the right colour but out of sequence. In an actual game, it's possible to get very lucky and simply guess the correct answer on your first attempt. In a computer simulation, on the other hand, it's possible for the computer to change the correct answer without telling you, as long as it doesn't contradict any previous information it has given you.  I.e. the computer is forcing a worst case scenario upon the guesser.  I've written just such a simulation here: https://github.com/IBwWG/cheatermind My question for you is this: Is it possible, given a configuration of $C >= 2$ colours and $S >= 1$ slots, to determine a formula for the minimum number of moves one would have to make to win against a computer that's cheating this way? For example, the simplest configuration (like a coin toss) would have $M(2,1) = 2$, because the first guess will always be wrong, leaving only one other possibility.  No matter what you guess, it will take a minimum of two guesses to win.

title: How many $three$-term Machin-like formulas using unit fractions and $\arctan \big(\frac{1}{239}\big)$ are there?

There are exactly four 2-term Machin-like formulas where the arctan argument is a unit fraction , namely,
$$\begin{aligned}
\frac{\pi}{4} 
&=\arctan\frac{1}{2} + \arctan\frac{1}{3}\\
&=2 \arctan\frac{1}{2} - \arctan\frac{1}{7}\\
&=2 \arctan\frac{1}{3} + \arctan\frac{1}{7}\\
&=4 \arctan\frac{1}{5} - \arctan\frac{1}{239}
\end{aligned}$$ ( Updated question: ) Using a rather basic Mathematica code, I found twenty-four 3-term formulas using only unit fractions and the constraint that one denominator $d>100$. However, almost half use $d=239$, namely $$\begin{aligned}
\frac{\pi}{4} 
&=4 \arctan\frac13 -4 \arctan\frac18-\arctan\frac1{239}\\
&=2\arctan\frac17+4\arctan\frac18+\arctan\frac1{239}\\
&=4\arctan\frac17+4\arctan\frac1{18}-\arctan\frac1{239}\\
&=8\arctan\frac18-4\arctan\frac1{18}+3\arctan\frac1{239}\\
&=4\arctan\frac14-4\arctan\frac1{21}-\arctan\frac1{239}\\
&=4\arctan\frac16+4\arctan\frac1{31}-\arctan\frac1{239}\\
&=6\arctan\frac17-4\arctan\frac1{57}+\arctan\frac1{239}\\

&=12\arctan\frac1{18}+8\arctan\frac1{57}-5\arctan\frac1{239}\\
&=8\arctan\frac1{10}-4\arctan\frac1{515}-\arctan\frac1{239}\\
\end{aligned}$$ with the third to the last appearing here , the second to the last being Gauss's Machin-Like formula , and the last in here (courtesy of Leibovici's comment). Questions : Is the list above complete for $d=239$? And why do so many formulas use $d=239$?

title: Limit measuring failure of sum-set cancellability
body: Suppose $A$, $B$ are finite sets of positive integers. Let $$\mathcal{S}_n =  \{C \subset [1,n] \, : \, A+C = B+C \}, $$ and denote $a_n = |\mathcal{S}_n|$. Note that for any $X \in \mathcal{S}_n$ and $Y \in \mathcal{S}_m$, the set $X \cup (Y+n) \subset [1,m+n]$ is in $\mathcal{S}_{m+n}$, hence $a_m \cdot a_n \le a_{m+n}$ for all $m$, $n$. By Fekete's Lemma, it follows that $$m(A, B) :=  \lim_{n\to\infty} \sqrt[n]{a_n}$$ exists and is finite, in particular $0\le m(A, B) \le 2$. If $A$ and $B$ do not have the same least and greatest elements, then $m(A,B) = 0$; if they do, then $m(A,B) \ge 1$. If $A = B$, then $m(A,B) = 2$. What can we say about $m(A,B)$ in general? Can we compute it given $A$ and $B$?

title: On the equivalence of representations of Fourier series
body:
Let $f : \Bbb{R} \to \Bbb{C}$ be a $2\pi$-periodic function such that
$$
\int_0^{2\pi} |f(t)| \,dt < \infty
$$ Define
$$
\hat{f}(k) := \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} f(t) e^{-i k t} \,dt
$$ The Fourier series of $f$ is then
$$
\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty}\hat{f}(k)e^{ikt} \tag{1}
$$ If we define
$$
a_k := \frac{1}{\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} f(t) \cos(kt) \,dt \quad (k \geq 1) \\
b_k := \frac{1}{\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} f(t) \sin(kt) \,dt \quad (k \geq 1)
$$
then the Fourier series of $f$ takes the form
$$
\hat{f}(0) + \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k \cos(kt) + \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k \sin(kt) \tag{2}
$$ In passing from $(1)$ to $(2)$, I have the following question (I'm led to think the answer is yes but haven't succeeded in proving it): If
  $$
\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left\{\hat{f}(n)[\cos(nt)+i\sin(nt)] + \hat{f}(-n)[\cos(nt)-i\sin(nt)]\right\} = \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} [a_k \cos(kt) + b_k \sin(kt)]
$$
  converges then do all four series
  $$
\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\hat{f}(n)[\cos(nt)+i\sin(nt)] \\ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\hat{f}(-n)[\cos(nt)-i\sin(nt)] \\
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k \cos(kt) \\
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} b_k \sin(kt)
$$

Suppose $T$ and $T'$ are tori in the compact Lie group $G$: "Since tori are compact and connected, if $T\subsetneq T'$, then dim $T < $ dim $T'$." I can see intuitively why this statement might be true, but how does one prove it?

title: Example of a nontransitive action of $\operatorname{Aut}(K/\mathbb Q)$ on the roots in $K$ of an irreducible polynomial.
body: I want to find an irreducible polynomial $f(x)$ over $\mathbb Q$ and a finite nonnormal extension $K/\mathbb Q$ which contains at least two roots of $f(x)$ such that $\operatorname{Aut}(K/\mathbb Q)$ acts nontransitively on the roots of $f(x)$ in $K$. I could not find simple examples of this. Update: Julian Rosen gave an answer to the original question above but now I want to impose the condition that $K$ is contained in the splitting field of $f(x)$ because I was looking for intermediate field extensions of the splitting field.

title: Is the intersection connected if union is simply connected?
body: It is well-known that intersection of connected sets is not necessarily connected. A standard example is two half-circles, which intersect in a discrete set $\{a,b\}$. However, Mayer-Vietoris says that if we replace things by path-connectedness and suppose that $X=\mathrm{int}(A)\cup \mathrm{int}(B)$ is simply connected, then the result holds. More precisely, given sets $A, B \subset X$ such that $A,B$ are path-connected and $X=\mathrm{int}(A) \cup \mathrm{int}(B)$ is simply connected, then $A \cap B$ is also path-connected (note the problem with the standard example: the circle is not simply connected). My question therefore is: does the above hold for connectedness? Explicitly, Given sets $A, B \subset X$ such that $A,B$ are connected and $X=\mathrm{int}(A) \cup \mathrm{int}(B)$ is simply connected, is $A \cap B$ connected?

title: How to prove the existence of non-intersecting subspaces?
body: Let $V=\Bbb R^n$, $P,P'$ two $k$-dim subspaces, there must exist a $(n-k)$-dim subspace $Q$ whose intersection with both $P$ and $P'$ is zero. Although I have no idea how to prove this result, I feel it might be somehow connected to this problem . Thanks for any help. EDIT I tried arguing analogously to Steve's answer to the linked problem, but I was just not sure how to make a proper analogy, or these two problems are not actually related at all. By the way, geometric intuition tells me the result is still true for any finite collection of $k$-dim subspaces.
